original: Your dreams might show you all kinds of insights into things that you didn't realise you were thinking about. Common dreams like being able to fly or falling, your teeth falling out or having no clothes on in a public place probably mean something similar in most people. But the key to understanding exactly what they mean to you is to connect them to the events and feelings in your daily life.
simplified: Your dreams can show you things you didn't know you were thinking about. Many people have the same dreams, like flying or falling, or their teeth falling out or being naked in a public place. These dreams are probably the same for everyone. But the key to understanding what they mean to you is to think about what is happening in your life.

original: One of the most interesting cases of wild animals living in a city are the wild dogs of Moscow. In Moscow, there are approximately 35,000 wild dogs living on the streets. Some of the dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned by their owners. Some dogs live alone and others live in packs. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs and found that the dogs have adapted remarkably successfully to urban life. They have learned that it is safer to cross the street with people and some dogs appear to understand traffic lights.
simplified: There are about 35,000 wild dogs in Moscow. Some dogs are born in the wild and others are pets that people have left behind. Some dogs live by themselves and others live in groups. Some dogs were born wild, while others are pets that have been abandoned. In 2010, scientists studied the dogs. They found that the dogs are very good at living in the city. They know it's safer to cross the street with people and some dogs even understand traffic lights.

original: Wonder is New Yorker RJ Palacio's first novel. On her website, she explains that the idea for the book came to her after seeing a girl with facial deformities on the street one day. The book is very popular in the United States and has won some awards. Many schools use it to talk about bullying, friendship and being different. A movie is being made. Many people are waiting to see what RJ Palacio writes next.

original: Chloe has two pet rats, Zena and Roxy. Chloe knows they're not typical pets and she has lost count of the times she's patiently tried to explain to people that rats aren't dirty and they make fantastic pets if you look after them correctly. But she understands why people react badly. She didn't like rats either until her friend Martin showed her his pet rats and she saw how affectionate and intelligent they were. Last year, when one of Martin's rats had babies, Chloe decided she'd like to have two of them.
simplified: I have two pet rats. Their names are Zena and Roxy. Some people think rats are not good pets because they're dirty. But I know this isn't true. Rats can make great pets if you take care of them. I used to think rats were not good pets too. But my friend Martin has rats and they are nice. They are friendly and smart. Last year, Martin's rat had babies. I saw them and I wanted two. So I got Zena and Roxy.

original: Cape Town can be a dangerous place for baboons. Some have been injured or killed in car accidents and others have been electrocuted as they played with electric cables. Baboons are an endangered species and to save them and minimise conflicts between humans and baboons, the city council has employed a team of Baboon Monitors. The monitors' job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This policy has had some success, though it is proving hard to stop baboons from coming back to the city once they see it as a source of easy food.
simplified: Cape Town can be a bad place for baboons. Some baboons get hurt or die in car accidents. Others get electrocuted when they play with electric wires. Baboons are an endangered species. They are in danger. To help them, the city council has a team to look after them. This team, called Baboon Monitors, chases baboons out of the city or catches them and takes them to the countryside. Their job is to chase baboons out of urban areas or catch them and release them in the countryside. This plan is working a little bit, but it is hard to keep baboons from coming back to the city. Baboons like to come back because they can easily find food there.

original: I work for a global IT company, but because their headquarters is in the States, I do all my work online from home. That means that I don't waste time commuting or making idle chit-chat with colleagues. This is good for me because I can take time off when my children need me to go to school. If I have a dentist appointment, I can also go then. But sometimes I work late into the evening and I don't eat dinner until I finish my work.

original: Social media, magazines and shop windows bombard people daily with things to buy, and British consumers are buying more clothes and shoes than ever before. simplified: People see many things to buy on social media, in magazines and in shop windows every day. British people are buying more clothes and shoes now than ever before. Online shopping makes it easy for people to buy things without thinking. Brands sell cheap clothes, so some people treat them like disposable items – wearing them a couple of times and then throwing them away.

original: Sam squinted against the sun at the distant dust trail raked up by the car on its way up to the Big House. The horses kicked and flicked their tails at flies, not caring about their owner's first visit in ten months. Sam waited. Mr Carter didn't come out here unless he had to, which was just fine by Sam. simplified: Sam looked at the dust trail from the car going up to the Big House. The horses were moving and swishing their tails at flies. Sam waited for Mr Carter. His shirt was wet and his skin was getting red from the sun because he was fair-skinned and got sunburned easily.

original: Many city residents in Berlin, Germany complained that shooting pigs was unnecessarily cruel and there were heated arguments between hunters and animal lovers. In response to protests, the city council decided to take more peaceful action against pigs. Instead of shooting them, they have put up fences and made it illegal to feed the pigs. Time will tell if this strategy works, though it may be a losing battle as warmer winters mean that pig numbers are greater than in the past.
simplified: People in Berlin, Germany were angry because hunters were shooting pigs. They thought it was cruel. Hunters and people who like animals argued a lot. The city council said they would do something else. They put up fences to keep the pigs out of the city. They also made a rule that people can't feed the pigs. Now we have to wait and see if this works. The winters are warmer now, so there are more pigs than before.

original: An important inspiration for the Hunger Games book comes from Suzanne's love of classical Greek mythology. When she was a child, one of her favourite stories was Theseus and the Minotaur. The youths were put in the labyrinth and a monster that lives there called the Minotaur ate them. But one of the youths, named Theseus, was brave and fought the Minotaur. He killed the monster. Suzanne thinks Katniss Everdeen is like Theseus.

original: By bringing people and animals together, zoos have the potential to educate the public about conservation issues and inspire people to protect animals and their habitats. Some zoos provide a safe environment for animals which have been mistreated in circuses, or pets which have been abandoned. Zoos also carry out important research into subjects like animal behaviour and how to treat illnesses.
simplified: Zoos help people learn about animals and their homes. They help people care for animals that are hurt or need a new home. Some zoos give a safe place to animals which have been hurt by people, or animals which people no longer want. Zoos do important research to help animals, like learning about animal behaviour and how to make them feel better when they are sick.

original: A different trend is springing up in opposition to consumerism – the 'buy nothing' trend. The idea originated in Canada in the early 1990s and then moved to the US, where it became a rejection of the overspending and overconsumption of Black Friday and Cyber Monday during Thanksgiving weekend. On Buy Nothing Day people organise various types of protests and cut up their credit cards. Throughout the year, Buy Nothing groups organise the exchange and repair of items they already own.
simplified:
People in the US and Canada are doing something new. They don't want to buy too many things. This is because they don't like buying a lot on Black Friday and Cyber Monday. These are big shopping days in the US.

One day, people protest against buying too much. They cut up their credit cards. People do this to say no to too much spending. Throughout the year, groups of people work together. They share things they already have. They also fix things that are broken.

original: Is graffiti art or vandalism? This depends on your point of view, but in many countries, writing or painting on public or private property is considered vandalism. simplified:
Is graffiti art or vandalism? 
Many people think it is vandalism. 
When you write or paint on public or private buildings, buses or trains, the police can stop you. 
City councils are unhappy because it is expensive to clean graffiti off buildings. 
They complain about the high cost.

simplified:
What do people in the art world think of graffiti and street art? 

They think graffiti and street art are important. There are big exhibitions in galleries in many cities, like Paris, London and Los Angeles. 

An American artist named Elura Emerald organised a big show of street art in a New York gallery in 2008. She said that artists who paint on the street are just expressing themselves and not hurting anyone. They should be appreciated and celebrated.

original: If most people have four to six dreams every night after the age of ten, that's as many as 2,000 dreams per year. So, by the time they reach 80 years old the average person might have had 140,000 dreams. Even if we forget 95–99 per cent of our dreams, that's still a few thousand remembered dreams across a lifetime. It's not too difficult to believe that, by coincidence, a dream event is followed by a real-life event that's similar to it, especially if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.
simplified: Many people have dreams every night. They have 4 to 6 dreams after they are 10 years old. This means they have 2,000 dreams every year. By the time they are 80 years old, they might have had 140,000 dreams. We forget most of our dreams, but we remember some. If we remember a few thousand dreams across a lifetime, it's not too difficult to believe that a dream event can be followed by a real-life event that's similar to it. This can happen if the subject of the dream is something that happens often in everyday life.

The Capitol has all the power. Each district makes different things for the Capitol. District 12 is where the story starts. They make coal for everyone. original: Often wild animals come into cities to look for food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons have started coming into residential areas on the edge of the city to feed. Wild animals come into cities to find food. In Cape Town, South Africa, baboons come into houses near the city to eat. They open bins and take fruit from gardens and orchards. Some baboons even go inside houses and take food from the kitchen.

original: A large number of bridge accidents occur during the construction of the bridge itself. These accidents are often due to an error made by the engineers, such as a miscalculation. The bridge collapses under its own weight, and this can be deadly for the workers on it at the time.
simplified: Many accidents happen when a bridge is being built. These accidents are often because of a mistake made by the engineers. They make a wrong calculation. The bridge can break down under its own weight. This can be very bad for the people working on the bridge at the time.

original: George Lucas was one of the early film directors to directly base his story on the 17 stages of the hero's journey. Typically the hero starts the story living an ordinary life, but something happens that calls them to an adventure that changes everything. At the beginning of Star Wars, Luke lives an ordinary life with his aunt and uncle, repairing robots. When he finds Princess Leia's message to Obi-Wan Kenobi inside the robot R2D2, it is 'the call to adventure' that starts the hero on his journey.
simplified:
George Lucas made a film called Star Wars. He used a special idea for the story. This idea has 17 steps. The hero starts with a normal life. Something happens that makes them go on a big journey.

In Star Wars, the hero is Luke. He lives with his aunt and uncle. They fix robots. Luke finds a message in a robot called R2D2. The message is from a princess. It is for a man named Obi-Wan Kenobi. This message starts Luke's big journey.

original: Another suggested defence against a PHA on course to hit Earth is to blow it up using a nuclear weapon. It may sound like a plot from a film, and it was the subject of the 1998 film Armageddon, but the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER) is a genuine NASA proposal. The eight-ton rockets would be fired at an approaching asteroid with the hope of bumping it off course. If the asteroid was too close to Earth for this plan to work, the rockets would carry nuclear bombs to blow it up instead.
simplified:
There is a way to stop a big rock from space from hitting Earth. It is called a PHA (Potentially Hazardous Asteroid). If one is coming towards us, we can try to move it off course. 

We can use special rockets. They are very big and strong. We fire them at the asteroid. We want them to bump it off course. If the asteroid is very close to Earth, we need to do something else. 

We can make the rockets carry special bombs. These bombs are very powerful. They can blow up the asteroid. This way, it will not hit Earth. This idea is called the Hypervelocity Asteroid Mitigation Mission for Emergency Response (HAMMER). It is a real NASA plan.

original: According to Campbell, the hero at first refuses the call to adventure, but a mentor appears who helps them and they decide to 'cross the threshold' and travel into the 'special world' where the adventure happens. The next stage consists of passing tests, fighting enemies and meeting friends as the hero prepares to face their biggest challenge. simplified:
According to Campbell, the hero at first says no to the adventure. But then a helper appears and they decide to go into a special place where the adventure happens. 

In Luke's story, his helper is Obi-Wan. He meets friends like Han Solo and the robots R2D2 and C3PO. But he also meets his enemy, Darth Vader, in a bad place called the Death Star.

original: Underutilised items may seem useless to some, but could be an asset to others. With the advent of the internet, online communities have figured out a way to generate profit from the sharing of those underused assets. Using websites and social media groups that facilitate the buying and selling of second-hand goods, it is now easier than ever for peer-to-peer sharing activities to take place. And this is known as the sharing economy.
simplified: We can use old things and they may seem useless, but they can be useful for someone else. With the internet, people have found a way to make money by sharing these old things with others. They use websites and social media groups to find people who want to buy or sell second-hand things. It is now easier for people to share things with each other, and this is known as the sharing economy.

original: Around the 18th and 19th centuries two main ideas about dreams became popular. One was the idea that the things we see in our dreams represent things hidden from our conscious mind. Freud believed that if we understand what dreams are telling us, we can understand our hidden feelings and the problems they cause. However, the other theory was the opposite. It said that dreams are just a collection of random activity in the brain while it's organising memories and events from the day. When we wake up, we try to make sense of these random images and feelings and put them into some sort of story.
simplified: A long time ago, two ideas about dreams were popular. One idea was that the things we see in our dreams are like secrets in our mind. They show us things we don't know about ourselves. A man called Freud said that if we understand our dreams, we can understand why we feel certain ways and why we have problems. But another person thought that dreams are just things that happen in our brain when it is working. It is like our brain is sorting out things from the day and then we try to make sense of it when we wake up.

original: I'm a freelancer and work for myself. This is great because I am in control of what I do and how I spend my time. At first, I was working from home, but I found it really hard to concentrate. There were just too many distractions around: housework that needed doing, another cup of tea, my family members wanting my attention for various things. So I started to go to a nearby café to work, but the Wi-Fi connection wasn't ideal and I found myself drinking too much coffee. In the end, I decided to rent a desk in a co-working space with five other freelancers like myself. I liked getting dressed to go to work in the morning and being able to focus in an office environment.
simplified: I work for myself. This is good because I have control of what I do and when I work. At first, I worked from home. But it was difficult for me to focus. There were too many things at home to do. I had to do housework and make tea. My family wanted my attention too. So, I went to a café near my home to work. But the Wi-Fi was not good and I drank too much coffee. Then, I rented a desk in a shared office with other people who work for themselves. I like dressing up to go to work and focusing in an office.

original: Whether NASA can find the remaining middle-sized NEOs depends on getting the money to build NEOCam, a 0.5-metre space telescope which would use infrared light to locate asteroids. If it did get the money, it could probably achieve its goal in ten years. Once logged, the planetary defence team would still need to work out how to defend the planet against being hit by the truly worrying asteroids – the PHAs.

NASA needs money to build a new telescope called NEOCam. It is a 0.5-metre space telescope that uses infrared light. If NASA gets the money, it will be able to find the middle-sized asteroids in ten years. 

When they find the middle-sized asteroids, the team will still have to work out how to protect the Earth from the big asteroids called PHAs.

original: The 'buy nothing' trend has now reached influencers on social media who usually share posts of clothing and make-up that they recommend for people to buy. Some YouTube stars now encourage their viewers not to buy anything at all for periods as long as a year. Two friends in Canada spent a year working towards buying only food. For the first three months they learned how to live without buying electrical goods, clothes or things for the house. For the next stage, they gave up services, for example haircuts, eating out at restaurants or buying petrol for their cars. In one year, they'd saved $55,000.
simplified:
Some social media stars now tell people not to buy things. They usually show us things to buy. Now they say don't buy anything for a year. Two friends in Canada did this. They wanted to buy only food for a year.

First, they learned to live without buying things like phones, clothes and home things. They did this for three months. Next, they stopped using services like haircuts, eating out and car petrol. They spent a year not buying things. In that year, they saved $55,000.

original: Religion is important to Pi. Though his family is Hindu, he is curious about other religions and he makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. To everyone's surprise, Pi declares himself to be simultaneously Hindu, Muslim and Christian. When his family and teachers ask him to choose just one religion, Pi refuses, saying 'I just want to love God'. From that moment, his family and teachers decide to let him make his own mind up about religion.
simplified: Pi's family is Hindu. He likes learning about other religions. He makes friends with a Christian priest and a Muslim baker. Everyone is surprised when Pi says he is Hindu, Muslim and Christian at the same time. His family and teachers ask him to choose just one, but Pi says he just wants to love God.

original: Some people think writing your dreams down can open your mind to lucid dreaming. Lucid dreams are dreams where you're not only aware you're dreaming but you can make decisions to affect the events of your dreams. So, maybe you can turn a nightmare into a safe-feeling dream, or you can direct the plot of your dream like a film director. Then, instead of just working out the meaning of your dreams, you'll be creating them, though you might want to continue having some dreams that allow your subconscious to tell you what's on your mind!
simplified: Some people think writing down your dreams can make your dreams more interesting. They call these dreams lucid dreams. In a lucid dream, you know you're dreaming and you can change what's happening. So, you can turn a bad dream into a good one or make the story of your dream happen the way you want it to. This way, instead of just thinking about what your dreams mean, you can make your own dreams.

original: People might not realise they are part of the disposable clothing problem because they donate their unwanted clothes to charities. But charity shops can't sell all those unwanted clothes. 'Fast fashion' goes out of fashion as quickly as it came in and is often too poor quality to recycle; people don't want to buy it second-hand. Huge quantities end up being thrown away, and a lot of clothes that charities can't sell are sent abroad, causing even more economic and environmental problems.
simplified: People think they're helping by giving old clothes to charity. But charity shops can't sell them all. The clothes people buy today are cheap and not good quality. They go out of fashion quickly and can't be recycled. People don't want to buy them again. Many old clothes are thrown away. Some charities send old clothes to other countries, but this causes more problems.

original: Not content with one amazing trip, some of today's adventurers go from challenge to challenge. Meagan McGrath from Canada has climbed the highest mountain on each continent, ridden a bike across Canada and run a long-distance race in the Sahara Desert in 45ºC heat. But perhaps her most remarkable journey was a skiing trip to the South Pole. On the first day, she fell into a glacier and had to be rescued. Many of us would have given up at that point, but Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later, having pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through freezing conditions and ice storms.
simplified:
Meagan McGrath from Canada likes to do many adventures. She climbed big mountains on every continent. She rode a bike across Canada and ran a long race in the hot Sahara Desert. She also went skiing to the South Pole.

On the first day, Meagan fell into a glacier. Many people would stop doing the trip at this point. But Meagan decided to carry on. She reached the South Pole forty days later. She pulled a sledge with a tent and all her food behind her through cold weather and ice storms.

original: Blek le Rat started out painting rats on the walls of his home city, Paris. Nowadays, he tries to make people think about different social issues and problems. He paints pictures of homeless people in big cities to encourage residents to think about the problem of homelessness.
simplified: Blek le Rat paints pictures in Paris. He started painting rats. Now he paints people in big cities to make people think about big problems. He paints pictures of people who don't have homes. He wants people to think about how to help them.

original: In some areas, councils have tried to encourage artists not to paint graffiti randomly on walls by allowing them to work in designated areas. Taiwan is one such place and there are 'graffiti zones' where artists are free to paint and write on walls. simplified: Some cities let artists paint on walls in special areas. In Taiwan, there are 'graffiti zones' where artists can paint and write on walls. In São Paulo in Brazil, the city council lets some artists paint on the city's subway trains.

original: Faith47 is from Cape Town in South Africa. She paints big, colourful pictures of people and animals and likes to explore different locations. Her work is found on pavements, in empty factories and on abandoned cars. She likes the fact that most street art is temporary and will soon be removed by weather or cleaners from the city council. original: In her previous work environment, Gabriela was used to a high power distance culture where power and authority are respected and everyone has their rightful place. In such a culture, leaders make the big decisions and are not often challenged. Her Swedish team, however, were used to working in a low power distance culture where subordinates often work together with their bosses to find solutions and make decisions. Here, leaders act as coaches or mentors who encourage independent thought and expect to be challenged.
simplified: Gabriela used to work in a place where bosses made big decisions. People respected the bosses and didn't often disagree. Now she works with a team in Sweden. They make decisions together with their bosses. Their bosses help and encourage them. They want people to think for themselves and make their own decisions.

original: When Gabriela became aware of the cultural differences between her and her team, she took the initiative to have an open conversation with them about their feelings about her leadership. simplified: Gabriela talked to her team about their feelings about her. She wanted to know what they thought. When she told her team what she needed them to do, they said they didn't like it. original: Os Gêmeos are identical twin brothers from São Paulo. They paint everything from tags to huge, colourful pictures of people on the sides of buildings. Their work is often so big that they need cranes to help them work. In 2007, they covered the whole of a castle in Scotland with paint.

They paint everything, from small tags to huge pictures of people. Sometimes, they need big machines like cranes to help them. In 2007, they painted a whole castle in Scotland.

original: People have been painting and writing on walls throughout history. In prehistoric times, people in Africa and Europe used to paint pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on buildings at ancient sites in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the Roman town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found numerous examples of graffiti written in Latin. These include religious, political and romantic messages, and even some magic spells!
simplified: People have been painting and writing on walls for a long time. In old times, people in Africa and Europe painted pictures of animals and people in caves. Graffiti has been found on old buildings in Greece, Italy, Syria and Iraq. In the town of Pompeii, archaeologists have found many messages written on the walls in a language called Latin. original: Have you ever dreamt of climbing Mount Everest or walking to the South Pole? If so, you're not alone. Every year, thousands of people try to climb the world's highest mountains or walk across continents. Unlike the explorers of the past who used maps and compasses, today's adventurers travel with modern technology like GPS and satellite phones. original: If we want to know where our capability for complex language came from, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This relates to more than just brain size; it is important what other things our brains can do and when and why they evolved that way. And for this there are very few physical clues; artefacts left by our ancestors don't tell us what speech they were capable of making. One thing we can see in the remains of early humans, however, is the development of the mouth, throat and tongue. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had evolved the ability to create complex sounds. Before that, evolutionary biologists can only guess whether or not early humans communicated using more basic sounds.
simplified: To know where we got our ability for complex language, we need to look at how our brains are different from other animals. This isn't just about how big our brains are, it's also about what our brains can do and when they changed. We can't find many clues from our ancestors that can help us understand this. However, we can see from the remains of early humans that their mouths, throats and tongues were changing. By about 100,000 years ago, humans had the ability to make complex sounds. Before that, scientists can only guess whether early humans communicated using more basic sounds.

original: It is society, not nature, that tells us girls should favour arts and humanities and leave maths and physics to the boys. If girls saw more positive female role models in science it would give them more confidence and a greater sense of belonging in those subjects.

original: Don't always follow positive feedback with negative feedback. When positive and negative feedback always appear to go hand in hand, the positives can become devalued and ignored. Ensure there are times when positive feedback is given for its own sake and resist the temptation to offer constructive criticism.
simplified:
When you give feedback, make sure to balance positive and negative comments. If you always give them together, people may start to ignore the positives. So, it's good to give them separately sometimes.

First, give feedback that is just positive. Don't always try to say something negative. This helps people feel good about what they did well. 

When you want to say something good, be specific. Instead of just saying "good job," say what you liked about it. For example, "I liked how you handled that difficult situation" or "Your work was clear and easy to understand."

Only say something negative when it's really needed. Don't bring up problems that aren't important or that the person already knows about.

When you do say something negative, focus on what the person did wrong, not on who they are as a person. Say what you want them to change, not what's wrong with them.

Use "I" statements to express your thoughts. Instead of saying "you did this wrong," say "I felt confused by this." This way, you're not attacking the person.

When you get feedback, listen carefully and think about what the other person is saying. This shows you value their opinion and are willing to learn from them.
